MULTITRANCHE FINANCING FACILITY AND INVESTMENT PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Islamic Republic of Pakistan 
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Energy 
Subsectors: Energy sector development 
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, environmental 
sustainability, and capacity development 
Subthemes:  Fostering  physical  infrastructure  development; 
cleaner  production,  control  of  industrial  pollution;  and 
organizational development 
   
Environment  The  subprojects  under  the  first  tranche  -  Category  B.  Initial 
Assessment  environmental examinations (IEE) undertaken. Summary IEE is 
given in Appendix 13. 
   
Investment Program  The  renewable  energy  development  investment  program 
Description  combines physical investments in new generating capacity across 
four  provinces  in  several  subsectors  and  nonphysical 
interventions  in  policy  reform,  capacity  development,  fiduciary 
oversight  and  governance,  regulatory  and  legal  frameworks, 
knowledge  management,  safeguards,  procurement, 
disbursements,  project  implementation,  evaluation,  supervision, 
monitoring and reporting.  
 
The investment program is the first of its kind in Pakistan. It is also 
one of the first to be developed under Asian Development Bank’s 
(ADB’s) evolving clean energy and environment initiative.  
 
The investment program has its context in a road map for the 
energy sector as a whole, in itself a product of diagnostic work 
over  recent  years.  The  starting  premise  for  this  work  is  a 
recognition  that  power  and  energy  represent,  together  with 
transport connectivity and water, major bottlenecks to high and 
inclusive economic growth in the country. Energy supplies are far 
too dependent on oil imports, the cost of which accounts for a big 
share of the total import bill. Pakistan needs to be more efficient in 
energy  use,  but  also  to  generate  more  power  domestically—
through the use of indigenous resources and by changing the mix 
towards renewable resources. The diagnostic work identified key 
constraints, challenges, and opportunities. This paved the way for 
defining a strategic framework, a new policy agenda, and action 
plans  over  the  short  to  medium  term.  The  action  plans  are 
sequenced and complementary, with transactions involving the 
private and public sectors, debt and equity finance, and technical 
assistance.  
 
Nationwide power demand is outstripping supply, a trend likely to 
continue  unabated  for  some  time.  To  balance  these,  Pakistan 
needs  to  increase  production  capacity  from  15,500  MW 
(megawatts) in 2005 to 162,590 MW by 2030.

ii   
  About 99,000 MW of this is likely to come from thermal power, i.e., 
coal, oil, and gas. But the balance could be met from hydropower 
and  renewable  energy,  which  potentially  are  environmentally 
friendlier. Hydro includes large, medium and small plants. This 
program  focuses  on  small  to  medium  plants  with  significant 
environmental benefits. 
   
  Total generation capacity from renewable energy (RE) is currently 
at a low 180 MW. But there is considerable scope and opportunity 
to increase it to 9,700 MW by 2030. This will raise RE’s profile and 
its contribution to the total energy mix to 6%. This contribution 
would  be  much  higher  were  medium  to  large  hydropower 
generation facilities to be included under the RE package.  
   
  Pakistan’s renewable energy potential is greatest in the case of  
small to medium-sized hydropower plants, but wind, solar, and 
biomass resources also have potential. Hydropower resources are 
located mainly in the northern and central parts of the country, 
wind and solar resources in the southern provinces of Sindh and 
Balochistan,  respectively.  Pakistan’s  vast  agricultural  base 
provides ample opportunities to develop biomass-based energy. 
   
  RE  delivers  on  four  strategic  objectives  given  in  Pakistan’s 
Medium  Term  Development  Framework  (MTDF):  (i)  greater 
energy security; (ii) reasonable economic and financial returns; 
(iii) improved social equity, especially in rural areas; and (iv) clean 
energy and environmental sustainability.  
 
The  investment  program  for  the  power  sector  as  a  whole  is 
estimated  to  be  $150  billion  (2006–2030)  with  $2.2  billion 
expected  for  RE.  Of  RE,  half  would  be  run-of-the-river  hydro 
plants. The rest is assigned to wind energy, solar power, and 
biomass.  The  financing  plan  involves  federal  and  provincial 
government budgets, but also the private sector and institutions 
such as ADB.  
 
The fund-raising strategy calls for a minimum critical mass but 
also for certainty and diversity of funding sources. A program of 
this nature cannot be easily supported on an ad hoc basis, i.e., 
through stand-alone projects processed every two to three years 
in different sectors and different parts of the country. The integrity 
of the investment program as a whole demands a partnership and 
continuity.  It  also  means  flexibility  with  regard  to  subproject 
choice,  a  linkage  of  finance  to  project  preparedness,  financial 
discipline,  and  maturing  physical  investments  with  policy  and 
capacity. It is in this context that the authorities requested ADB 
support for the program in the form of a multitranche financing 
facility (MFF). Such support provides a platform for financial as 
well  as  expert  assistance,  blending  reform  and  capacity 
development with investments.

iii 
Policy Framework  The RE sector is backed by a policy framework. This is the result 
of diagnostic work that led to the sector road map and investment 
program. The framework has measures for each of the four RE 
subsectors and provinces. It distinguishes between policies at the 
federal  and  provincial  levels.  North-West  Frontier  Province 
(NWFP) and Punjab have already completed their draft policies. 
The other two provinces are working on theirs.  
 
Preparation of the final policy framework and implementation in 
each province (as well as at the federal level) will be supported by 
a special technical assistance package financed under the MFF. 
There will be a cross-conditionality between investments, future 
funding from ADB and RE policy reforms. Policies are purposely 
broad to start with; and not “cast in stone”. The starting point is 
establishment of basic principles and criteria for RE development. 
During the implementation phase, adjustments are possible and 
likely. Enabling conditions will thus differ in scope and depth over 
time.  The  program  represents  a  partnership  between  the 
Government and ADB. This means that ADB and others will have 
ample  opportunities  to  suggest  changes.  For  this  to  happen, 
sound monitoring and reporting is a precondition. The process 
needs  good  information.  Changes  to  the  framework  will  be 
reported on a regular basis to ADB’s Management and the Board. 
   
Capacity Development  The  diagnostic  work  undertaken  in  support  of  the  program 
identified  weak  capacity  at  the  federal,  provincial,  and 
implementation agency levels. Weaknesses differ in importance 
and magnitude, but include policy formulation, planning, project 
preparation,  financial  management,  fiduciary  oversight, 
governance  in  the  broader  sense  (incentives  to  private  sector 
investment), procedures, systems, safeguards, and procurement. 
There is also weakness with regard to evaluation, monitoring, and 
reporting. The latter include procedures, systems and expertise.  
 
The  investment  program  includes  a  strong  capacity 
development component. This will support executing agencies 
(EAs) and implementing agencies (IAs) alike. Key result areas 
include (i) information, planning, policy framework formulation and 
revisions thereof; (ii) human resources development and training; 
(iii)  sector  and  thematic  due  diligence,  including  technical 
feasibility studies, and RE resource assessments; (iv) systems 
and procedures for project supervision, monitoring, and reporting; 
(v)  due  diligence  and  mitigation  plans  (with  emphasis  on 
safeguards);  (vi)  fiduciary  oversight,  including  financial 
management,  procurement,  anticorruption  measures,  and 
governance; (ix) project management, including accounting and 
auditing; and (x) outreach work, including communications and 
public relations. 
   
The Alternative Energy Development Board (AEDB) will act as the 
main counterpart for ADB financing and for the program. Actual 
day-to-day work in the sector will be the mandate of specialized 
RE agencies at the provincial level.

iv   
  ADB  is  not  acting  alone.  The  World  Bank  and  United  States 
Agency for International Development (USAID) will work with ADB 
on capacity development. USAID will also provide direct support 
to the South Asia Regional Energy Initiative for Energy and assist 
sector agencies with collecting and assessing wind data. Finally, 
AEDB is already receiving specialized technical support from the 
German  Agency  for  Technical  Cooperation  (Deutsche 
Gesellschaft  für  Technische  Zusammenarbeit),  primarily  with 
project preparation techniques.  
 
Multitranche Financing  The Government has requested $510 million from ADB to support 
Facility  the program. This is to be structured around an MFF with a life 
span  of  10  years.  This  financing  represents  23%  of  the  total 
financing  plan.  The  MFF  will  allow  the  authorities  to  finance 
individual  projects  as  the  projects  and  conditions  warrant  by 
linking financing to project readiness, reforms, capacity, and work 
on various themes. Individual periodic financing requests (PFR) 
will be the means to convert parts of the MFF into individual loans. 
The authorities underwrite to ADB their adherence in full and at all 
times  of  basic  policies  and  procedures  via  warranties  and 
representations  made  in  a  Framework  Financing  Agreement 
(FFA)  and  with  assistance  of  the  capacity  development 
component.  These  warranties  and  representations  cover  basic 
technical operating principles at the subproject level, criteria and 
rules related to broad sector development in the broader sense,  
subproject  criteria  and  the  application  of  all  standard  and 
prevailing  ADB  policies  and  procedures  regarding  safeguards, 
governance, anticorruption, financial management, procurement, 
and disbursement. To help agencies comply with these warranties 
and  representations,  the  Government  accepts  the  fielding  of 
teams of experts under the capacity development component. The 
teams will include expertise to carry out quality due diligence but 
also modern management techniques to execute changes and 
report on results. Safeguards, governance, and procurement are 
areas where the greatest help is required. ADB will also provide 
direct  advice  on  a  regular  basis  through  its  own  program 
implementation  missions.  This  transaction  requires,  and  will 
receive, higher than average attention from ADB teams. Capacity 
development is one of the main success factors.  
 
Framework Financing  The  Government  has  entered  into  an  FFA  with  ADB  for  the 
Agreement  purposes  of  the  investment  program.  The  FFA  satisfies  the 
requirements set forth in Appendix 4 of the Board Paper on Pilot 
Financing Instruments and Modalities. Pursuant to the FFA, the 
Government has submitted to ADB a first PFR in an amount of 
$115 million. The first PFR is presented to the Board together with 
the MFF and the FFA.  
 
The FFA records the full set of warranties and representations 
highlighted  above.  These  cover  ADB  operating  policies  and 
procedures on all crosscutting themes.  
 
Prior  to  ADB  acceptance  of  a  PFR,  it  is  understood  that  the 
Government and participating provinces and their RE agencies

v 
  will ensure they comply in full with the terms and conditions of the 
FFA. The capacity development component will provide support.  
It will do so by helping with specific due diligence and with the 
development of corresponding mitigation plans. ADB teams will 
evaluate all funding requests and check these to ensure that they 
satisfactorily adhere to representations made and will continue to 
do  so.  ADB  teams  will  provide  ongoing  guidance  to  the 
authorities,  and,  if  needed,  make  available  additional  experts 
under the capacity development component. ADB staff will report 
to the Government, Management and the Board on the status of 
individual  loans,  including  the  performance  on  warranties  and 
representations.  Failure  to  comply  with  any  of  these  will 
automatically hold back additional finance under the MFF.  
 
Rationale  The  Government  has  delegated  authority  to  the  provinces  to 
develop power generating capacity of up to 50 MW. RE programs 
are  a  means  to  deliver  this  mandate.  In  May  2005,  the 
Government announced a target calling for RE to reach 3.5% and 
6.0%  of  the  total  energy  supply  mix  by  2015  and  2030, 
respectively.  RE  development  is  compatible  with  the 
Government’s  twin  goals  of  energy  security  and  promoting 
indigenous resource utilization. RE development is also one of the 
key  features  of  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  and 
environmental agendas. RE supports electrification in remote and 
rural  areas,  including  those  not  covered  by  the  main  grid. 
Employment  generation  and  improvements  in  social  well-being 
are two by-products of RE development.  
   
Impact and Outcome  The investment program will contribute to economic development 
through expanded power supply, especially in rural areas. It will 
generate  energy  equivalent  to  1,700  gigawatt-hours  (GWh) 
annually,  sufficient  to  serve  about  600,000  new  domestic 
consumers. It will improve the reliability and quality of supply. It 
will also increase the utilization of clean and RE-based power. 
   
First PFR  The MFF transaction is accompanied by a first PFR to finance a 
set  of  subprojects  prepared  by  the  provinces  and  ready  for 
implementation.  The  investments  comprise  mainly  small  to 
medium-sized hydropower plants in NWFP and Punjab. This first 
loan  also  covers  capacity  development.  The  first  PFR  is 
representative  of  others  to  be  forthcoming  and  takes  in  three 
major areas: 
 
Clean Energy Development. This includes expansion of small 
hydropower  generating  capacity.  The  main  components  are 
construction of thee grid-connected plants in NWFP ranging from 
  2.6 MW to 36 MW and five small to medium-sized hydropower 
stations in Punjab ranging from 3.2 MW to 7.2 MW. The total 
capacity will be about 75 MW, which will generate about 400 GWh 
of annual energy output.

vi   
   
Feasibility Studies and Other Due Diligence of New Sites. The 
first  PFR  will  support  preparation  of  eight  additional  feasibility 
studies involving new sites in NWFP (three) and Punjab (five). 
These will be converted into subprojects for financing under a new 
PFR. The feasibility studies include due diligence on technical, 
financial, commercial, regulatory, operational, governance, legal, 
fiduciary oversight, safeguards, procurement, and implementation 
matters. The work will be carried out by teams of experts. ADB will 
advise  on  their  terms  of  reference,  in  particular  on  the 
requirements to comply with ADB operating rules and procedures. 
 
Capacity Development. This component will support work at the 
federal,  provincial,  and  project  levels  and  provide  for  better 
planning,  policy  work,  training,  financial  management,  fiduciary 
oversight,  tariff  setting,  institutional  strengthening,  project 
management, safeguards, evaluation, monitoring, and reporting. It 
will also include sector information and technical backup expertise 
to deliver efficiencies. Whereas the feasibility study work above 
focuses  on  project  preparation,  backed  by  due  diligence  on 
various  project  related  areas  (identifying  risks  and  mitigation 
plans), the capacity development component combines help to the 
agencies  in  meeting  project  loan  obligations  today  with 
development  for  the  future  of  smart  and  sustainable  planning, 
policy formulation, systems, procedures, institutions, and trained 
people,  as  well  as  sound  criteria  and  rules  to  ensure  sector 
growth, efficiency, effectiveness and results.  
 
Project Investment Plan  The total cost of the RE program runs to $2.2 billion. Total cost of 
the projects included in the first PFR is $145 million equivalent.

MFF Amount and Terms  The maximum financing amount available under the MFF is $510 
million.  It  combines  $500  million  from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources and $10 million from Special Funds resources. 
 
The governments of NWFP and Punjab will convert the facility into 
several loans or tranches.1 Indicative loan amounts are 
  $180 million and $150 million (total $330 million), respectively. 
Other provinces will request funding for RE projects and follow the 
warranties  and  representations  set  forth  in  the  FFA.  Their 
financing requirements are estimated at $170 million. 
                                                 
1  Tranche and set of loans are used interchangeably.

vii 
   
  Each loan under the MFF would be at least $50 million and would 
be used to partially finance RE development projects. Final terms 
and conditions will be determined in the context of each individual 
loan and be based on prevailing policies within ADB. Financing 
from OCR resources will be subject to interest to be determined in 
accordance with ADB’s London Interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility and such other terms and conditions set 
forth in the related loan and project agreements. ADB will also 
provide  a  $10  million  loan  in  Special  Drawing  Rights  from  its 
Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 
1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum 
thereafter; a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years, 
to  support  such  investments  as  institutional  and  capacity 
development, as well as feasibility studies. The borrower will be 
the Islamic Republic of Pakistan.  
   
  The proceeds of the loans will be made available to the provinces 
on the same terms and conditions as applicable to the borrower. 
The foreign exchange risk will be borne by the borrower. The 
utilization period will be 10 years, from 2007 to 2017. 
   
Period of Utilization  A 10-year implementation period is proposed for the MFF from 
2007 to 2017 with the last PFR to be submitted by 31 December 
2015. Each specific loan will have its own closing date to match 
with its implementation period. 
   
Executing Agencies and  The AEDB will be the EA at the federal level. At the provincial 
Implementing Agencies   government  level,  the  program  will  be  executed  via 
special-purpose IAs. 
 
The subprojects under the first PFR will cover two provinces—
NWFP and Punjab. Accordingly, irrigation and power departments 
(IPDs) of the governments of NWFP and Punjab will be their EAs 
The  IAs  will  be  the  Sarhad  Hydel  Development  Organization 
(SHYDO) in NWFP, and Punjab IPD in Punjab (the latter until the 
Punjab Power Development Company Limited is established and 
becomes  operational).  SHYDO  has  established  one  project 
management unit (PMU), which is in its main office in Peshawar. 
The PMU director and field-level project managers have already 
been appointed. They report all subproject-related matters to the 
Director, Planning and Facilitation of SHYDO, who is ex-officio the 
overall coordinator for the NWFP component. 
 
A PMU has also been established in Punjab IPD, headed by a 
project director. Several key staff members have been assigned to 
carry out preparatory work, including documentation to approve 
Project Concepts-1, initial environmental examinations, and the 
execution  of  resettlement  plans.  The  team  will  also  undertake 
advance  actions  in  recruiting  consultants  and  later  handle 
procurement. At the same time, Punjab IPD has taken preparatory

viii  
  steps to establish a company,  wholly owned by the provincial 
government,  to  manage  the  construction  of  and  to  own  and 
operate hydropower plants. A draft charter of the company, the 
Punjab  Power  Development  Company  Limited,  has  been 
prepared. The Province has endorsed the plan and it is expected 
that the company will be legally established, fully staffed, and 
functioning  before  31  December  2006.  Once  the  company  is 
operational,  the  tasks  of  the  PMU  will  be  taken  over  by  the 
company and therefore the company will become the IA.  
   
Procurement  Equipment and materials to be financed under the MFF will be 
procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines, 
2006, as amended from time to time. International competitive 
bidding (ICB) will be used for turnkey contracts for construction of 
all hydropower plants and for supply contracts estimated to cost 
the equivalent of or more than $1.5 million. Limited international 
bidding will be used for supply contracts estimated at $100,000 to 
$1.0 million, and national competitive bidding (NCB) will be used 
for  contracts  worth  less  than  $100,000.  Civil  works  contracts 
estimated at less than $1.0 million will be procured following NCB 
procedures  acceptable  to  ADB.  Contract  packages  will  be 
prepared  to  ensure  maximum  competition  under  ICB.  Similar 
contractual  arrangements  and  specifications  will  be  applied  to 
other subprojects.  
 
The proceeds of individual loans under the MFF will be disbursed 
  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook  and 
ADB’s Interim Guidelines for Disbursement Operations, LIBOR-
Based Loan Products, both as periodically amended. 
   
Consulting Services  Consulting services will be required for (i) design, supervision, and 
management under Part A; (ii) feasibility studies under Part B; 
and(iii) capacity development under Part C. Consultants will be 
selected and engaged in accordance with Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants by ADB and its Borrowers, 2006, as amended from 
time to time. Services will be provided through consulting firms 
chosen by international competition using the quality and cost-
based  selection  method.  Individual  experts  may  be  recruited 
based  on  biodata  submitted  in  response  to  specific  terms  of 
reference for the assignment. 
    
Benefits and  The investment program is designed to benefit all grid-connected 
Beneficiaries of the  consumers of electricity by expanding electric power supplies and 
Investment Program  will  enable  the  Government  to  meet  its  objective  of  universal

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Pakistan is a net importer of energy. Over the last 5 years, on average it has spent about 
$3.3 billion annually on imported energy, equivalent to 25% of the total import bill. Oil is the 
main cost item. During the current fiscal year (2006) this cost is likely to exceed $6 billion–a 
function of both demand and price increases. Oil imports place a heavy burden on foreign 
exchange reserves. More than 65% of Pakistan’s electricity comes from thermal sources, a little 
less than 30% from hydro, and less than 1% from renewable and other sources. Despite 
imports, Pakistan’s power supplies are 20% less than they should be. In addition, only 55% of 
the  population  has  access  to  electricity  from  the  national  grid.  The  remaining  45%  use 
kerosene, fuel wood, and other forms of biofuels for lighting, cooking, and heating. Pakistan has 
one of the lowest per capita energy consumptions2 in the world.  
 
3.  Pakistan’s Medium Term Development Framework (MTDF) sets out a strategic vision 
and investment program for the sector for the period 2005–2010. The main objective of this 
program is to support a projected 6–8% growth in gross domestic product (GDP). Energy is 
essential to high and inclusive growth. The poverty reduction agenda depends on it. A results 
framework is given in Appendix 1. A detailed analysis of the sector is provided in Supplementary 
Appendix A. 
 
4.  The  vision  for  the  sector  has  four  main  components:  (i)  increased  private  sector 
investment in the entire production chain; (ii) reduced technical, non-technical and financial 
losses;  (iii)  improved  sustainability  and  reduced  level  of  government  subsidies;  and  (iv) 
improved service delivery, efficiency, and governance in the energy utilities. The strategy will 
deliver various key outcomes: (i) basic sector reforms to create an enabling environment for 
private sector participation; (ii) better sector analysis and stronger capacity among the relevant 
sector organizations, including in such areas as financial management, governance, operational 
efficiency, clean development mechanisms, and project management; and (iii) promotion of 
infrastructure development projects in generation, distribution, and transmission, while including 
renewable energy  development. The latter will target industry, as well as urban and rural 
communities. 
 
5.  Annual electricity demand growth is forecast to average 8.3% during 2005–2015. To 
cope with this demand growth, Pakistan needs annually an additional 2,000 megawatts (MW) of 
newly installed capacity. The estimated annual investment cost to deliver this capacity is about 
$6 billion. This additional generated power would need to be evacuated through the formal 
transmission network to consumers through the distribution system. The transmission system

  6.   Lessons Learned 
 
20.  Ten power projects approved up to 1983 have been postevaluated. All of these projects 
were  classified  as  generally  successful.  Nonetheless,  the  postevaluation  findings  show 
problems needing to be avoided in future. The most critical are delays in implementation and 
cost overruns. The average implementation delay was 2.4 years (with more than three quarters 
of the projects delayed by some 78% of their planned targets). Five of the projects experienced 
an average cost overrun of 82%, and the other five an average underrun of 28%. There are 
differences between the various segments of the power sector chain. Transmission projects 
have  performed  better  than  others.  ADB-financed  projects  after  1983  show  better  results. 
However, Karachi Electric Supply Corporation and WAPDA (two clients since that time) have 
not delivered on operational targets, in particular regarding system loss-reductions. ADB has yet 
to finance RE projects in Pakistan.  
 
21.  Three other lessons can be taken from ADB’s past involvement in Pakistan’s power 
sector. First, weak governance influences effectiveness and performance on the ground. This 
remained a concern until the authorities established NEPRA as an independent regulator. Since 
then, NEPRA has received considerable financial and technical support from the Government 
and external agencies and, on the whole, it has been doing a good job. Second, the reform 
package did not specifically cater for private sector participation. This limited the entry of private 
funding,  better  technology,  and  modern  management  practices.  It  also  affected  efficiency, 
competition, productivity, and commercial focus. Third, the funding agencies, including ADB, did 
not invite civil society to participate in a systematic and active fashion at the time of project 
formulation.  This  may  have  discouraged  some  reforms,  accountability,  good  governance, 
competition, and the development of consumer advocacy groups.  
 
22.  The project team has taken these lessons, along with others from other countries, into 
account when working on the proposed investment program. The regulator continues to function 
well, although it will be further strengthened through direct support from other agencies, namely 
the  World  Bank.  AEDB  is  the  more  direct  counterpart  for  RE  development.  This  will  be 
supported  directly  by  ADB  through  special  TA.  A  capacity  development  component  is 
incorporated into the proposed program, targeting broad RE sector constraints and specific 
subproject issues. Reforms revolve around tariffs, governance, and private sector involvement. 
Tariff  setting  has  improved  considerably,  as  demonstrated  in  recent  hydropower  projects, 
namely Malakand III and New Bong Escape. The tariff regime will be further fine-tuned for the 
purposes of new RE hydro projects. Tariff setting for wind farms, biomass, and solar will also be 
improved. The latter is already happening in provinces such as Sindh where the objective has 
been to find a formula to entice private investment. The approved indicative (up-front) tariff for

captures the main outcomes (Appendix 1). This framework will provide a guide for regular

the rest to Karachi Electric Supply Corporation. ADB has been the major source of external 
assistance to the energy sector, providing about one third of total external resources. ADB’s 
nonlending  activities  have  also  been  important,  totaling  $14.2  million  for  27  TA  projects

24.  The energy sector in Pakistan needs to grow by 12% annually to sustain a GDP growth 
rate of 8%. The country direly needs to generate and evacuate more power in the coming years. 
Shortages are already expected during 2006–2007, the gap reaching some 5,500 MW by 
2009/10 unless new investment takes place. ADB’s project pipeline in the medium term focuses 
on transmission and distribution, with RE as the third pillar. Generation sector investments likely 
will be driven by the private sector. ADB can also play a role here through individual transaction 
support. The Government is stepping up efforts to develop more indigenous resources, in 
particular those based on hydel. ADB and the World Bank already have been asked to assist 
the Government and private sector in this area. Both institutions will contribute finance and 
expertise but also “best practice” ideas on such key thematic issues as governance, financial 
management, procurement, anticorruption, and safeguards (environmental and social).  
 
25.  ADB’s sector strategy focuses on reform, investment and capacity. The reform agenda 
targets creation of an enabling environment for private and public investment alike. It also 
targets development of better tariff regimes, stronger financial management systems, regulation, 
governance, and measures to facilitate and keep private sector investment. The investment 
agenda focuses on new facilities and rehabilitation of existing ones, along the chain from supply 
through transmission and distribution. It emphasizes indigenous resources, with a focus on 
hydropower. That agenda also attaches priority to renewable energy development (to help 
change the energy mix and increase supplies in rural areas) and energy efficiency. The capacity 
agenda  focuses  on  better  regulation  and  regulators;  more  efficient  facilitating  agencies 
(including those working on developing public-private partnerships); and improved planning, 
evaluation, monitoring and reporting, and fiduciary oversight. The platform for this strategy is 
poverty reduction and effectiveness. It works on selected bottlenecks to sector development, 
which, in turn, is a bottleneck to rising and inclusive growth.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
 
26.  The investment program in RE development will help change the energy mix but also cut 
poverty and improve welfare in rural areas. It will further the agenda on clean energy and the 
environment while making use of indigenous resources. It will deliver on these objectives by 
combining physical investments in new facilities with reforms and capacity development. The 
program will be phased and sequenced. The project team and authorities have produced a 
matrix matching RE subsectors to provincial, reform, and subproject readiness. The program 
will start with run-of-the-river small hydro plants in Punjab and NWFP. While this gets off the

8   
ground,  project  preparation  and  reform  and  institutional  changes  will  be  put  in  place  in 
Balochistan  and  Sindh.  These  are  provinces  better  suited  for  wind,  solar,  and  biomass 
investments. The phased approach does not overstretch the capacity at AEDB and on the 
ground. It gives time to plan, fine-tune reforms, and learn from experiences in Punjab and 
NWFP.  It  allows  ADB  teams  to  put  in  place  efficient  project  monitoring,  supervision,  and 
reporting systems, as well as procedures and mechanisms. The program’s success will depend 
on implementation, and that will be driven by the quality of people and systems on the ground.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
27.  The investment program will contribute to economic development and well-being through 
expanded power supply. It will generate 1,700 gigawatt-hours (GWh) annually, sufficient to 
service about 600,000 new connections or 4.8 million people. It will improve the reliability and 
quality of supply. It will also increase the share of clean and renewable energy in the total 
energy mix from 0.9% in 2005 to 3.5% in 2015.  
 
28.  The program starts with a first batch of subprojects. These provide an accurate picture of 
what will come on stream in the short to medium term in two provinces in that subsector— 
hydropower— that is most ready and has high priority. This first batch has been bundled into a 
first periodic financing request (PFR) that will become the first loan conversion from the global 
MFF  facility.  The  subprojects  include  investments  in  small  to  medium-sized  hydropower 
development  in  NWFP  and  Punjab.  Equally  important,  it  includes  help  in  moving  project 
preparation forward and with capacity development at three different levels. This link between 
investment and noninvestment interventions is the main feature of an MFF. It is also the basis 
for long-term partnership and providing support services on the ground. This support is provided 
when  it  most  matters—during  implementation  of  the  program.  It  focuses  on  outcomes, 
effectiveness, and results, rather than just on inputs or compliance. The main outputs are: 
 
(i)  Part  A:  clean  energy  development  investments.  This  includes  the 
development and/or expansion of small to medium-sized hydropower generation 
plants. Three of these will be grid-connected plants ranging from 2.6 MW to 36 
MW. These will be located in NWFP. The first batch will also include five small 
hydropower stations ranging from 3.2 MW to 7.2 MW in the Punjab.  
 
(ii)  Part B: feasibility studies and due diligence for new sites. The first loan will 
finance  the  services  of  experts  to  work  on  preparing  eight  new  hydropower 
proposals in NWFP and Punjab. This work includes detailed due diligence on all 
standard  project  finance  areas  associated  with  ADB-financed  transactions, 
namely  technical,  commercial,  legal,  regulatory,  operational,  management, 
governance,  capacity,  financial  management,  fiduciary  oversight,  and 
safeguards. The work will also include preparing advance actions on consulting 
services, procurement, and documentation for the clearance of project concepts 
in  the  internal  government  system.  The  objective  is  to  close  the  time  gap 
between  the  approval  dates  for  subproject  finance  and  the  start-up  of  their 
implementation. One feature of this due diligence package is to ensure that all 
ADB operational policies and procedures are adhered to in full and at all times. 
The  team  of  experts  also  represents  an  entry  point  at  which  ADB  program 
implementation missions can check in advance the quality of work on the ground 
and give advice. ADB will evaluate the terms of reference of the consultants and 
provide guidance to them and the government agencies on a regular basis. It will 
monitor  the  past  (performance  on  the  first  PFRs)  and  any  ongoing  project

9
preparatory work. The objective is to identify problem areas at an early stage and 
to collaborate in defining appropriate solutions. In case of compliance-related 
matters,  the  consultations  will  involve  the  relevant  teams  in  Manila  and  the 
Resident Mission.  
 
(iii)  Part  C:  Capacity  Development.  This  will  support  establishment  of  new 
evaluation,  monitoring,  and  reporting  systems  at  the  federal,  provincial,  and 
implementation agency levels. It will also define and execute a program to help 
improve strategy and policy formulation and planning, knowledge management 
(regarding sector development issues and project best practice worldwide), staff 
coaching and training, financial management systems and practices, fiduciary 
oversight, accounting and auditing and financial reporting. The program will also 
work on institutional strengthening (including changing the mandates of some 
entities). 
  
C.  Technical Justification and Selection Criteria 
 
29.  All  selected  subprojects  under  the  first  PFR  have  been  subjected  to  assessments 
required under ADB policies and procedures. Initially, the subprojects were checked by local 
and provincial agencies against technical and other criteria. The reports were then submitted to 
federal agencies for additional reviews and approval. ADB-funded project preparatory technical 
assistance consultants worked on various aspects of the proposed subprojects. ADB processing 
missions visited several project sites, reviewed available information and reports, and undertook 
comprehensive due diligence assessments on a range of areas (including safeguards). All 
subprojects included in the first loan meet ADB criteria and operating policies and procedures. 
Future financing submissions under the MFF facility will undergo the same process, although 
the fieldwork will be undertaken by due diligence experts. The authorities provided ADB with a 
set of warranties and representations on several fronts. With regard to the actual subprojects, 
these warranties cover the following: 
 
(i)  The proposed subprojects will involve either new construction or rehabilitation of 
(a) small to medium-sized hydropower plants with installed capacity of not more 
than 50 MW, preferably run-of-the river schemes; (b) wind turbines; (c) solar 
cells; (d) biomass; or (e) other forms of renewable energy sources. 
(ii)  If grid-connected, the total capacity of each of the subprojects will not be less 
than 2 MW.  
(iii)  For each subproject, a feasibility study and support due diligence shall have 
been prepared. The feasibility study and due diligence will include the following 
aspects, among others: (a) technical design, including the proposed technology; 
(b)  economic  and  financial  viability,  including  the  tariff  requirement;  (c) 
operational sustainability, including maintenance and availability of spare parts; 
(d)  institutional  capacity  analysis;  (e)  environmental  analysis;  and  (f)  social 
assessments, and resettlement plans, following a proper consultation process. 
The  work  will  also  include  financial  management;  governance  and  fiduciary 
oversight;  as  well  as  procurement,  disbursement,  and  implementation  plans 
(including monitoring and reporting). 
(iv)  Each  proposed  subproject  will  meet  ADB  safeguard  requirements.  ADB 
compliance teams will review the proposals in advance of their being submitted 
for financing. 
(v)  The subprojects will be ranked using a least-cost expansion plan reviewed or 
assessed by means of an optimization program such as Wien Automatic System

10   
Planning (WASP)-IV, selecting subproject RE generation plants that contain: (a) 
the closest link to the national or provincial grid, (b) the high priority off-grid sites, 
and (c) other eligible ways to maximize social welfare or minimize unforeseen 
risks. 
(vi)  Each subproject will have been endorsed by the implementing agency, provincial 
government, and AEDB (on behalf of the Government). 
(vii)  Power generation plant safety measures will be incorporated into the subproject 
designs as required by appropriate national and international norms and values. 
(viii)  Design of subprojects will be based on inputs from community consultations 
conducted in accordance with the RE policy. However, the Government and/or 
ADB  may  from  time  to  time  require  that  additional  conditions  be  fulfilled  in 
subproject selection, as needed. 
(ix)  Each  participating  provincial  government  will  (a)  have  established  a  project 
management unit to implement the proposed subprojects, (b) commit to provide 
the  required  counterpart  funding  on  time,  and  (c)  agree  to  implement  the 
subprojects in accordance with the relevant ADB guidelines on procurement, 
recruitment  of  consultants,  disbursements,  financial  management,  fiduciary 
oversight (including anticorruption measures), and auditing requirements. 
 
30.  The investment program will also accommodate special pilot projects that are directly 
linked to, or closely associated with, RE development. For example, for some off-grid RE 
projects,  it  may  be  necessary  to  include  a  rural  electrification  or  community  management 
component to ensure project sustainability. There are also various pilot activities that may have 
potential to be scaled up but which have never been tested to assure their sustainability.  
 
D.  Special Features 
 
1.  Policy Support 
 
31.  The Government has prepared an RE policy framework for the sector. This is backed by 
provincial RE policies. Both NWFP and Punjab province have completed their drafts. These 
derive from a renewable energy development road map that was prepared by the Government. 
This maps out a list of problems, challenges, and opportunities while outlining a policy agenda 
for RE development in the short to medium term (up to 2010). The Government also prepared a 
follow-up investment program. ADB has been helping in all of these areas.  
 
2.  Capacity Development  
 
32.  The investment program combines investments with work on capacity development. The 
latter is weak (see Appendix 4 and, for details, Supplementary Appendix E). The Government 
has requested technical assistance support from ADB to formulate a comprehensive Renewable 
Energy  Policy  and  capacity  development  of  AEDB.  Details  of  the  proposed  Technical 
Assistance are given in Appendix 5 and Supplementary Appendix F. The capacity development 
component focuses on addressing bottlenecks at three separate levels: 
 
33.  Federal Level. The main target is to build AEDB’s capacity. Major funding agencies, 
including ADB, have already provided assistance. Further assistance is expected in future. It will 
focus on policy formulation, evaluation systems, monitoring and evaluation, and such human 
resources development as coaching and training. AEDB also needs up-to-date information on 
sector developments and best practice ideas on project and policy development.

11
34.  Provincial and Implementing Agency Levels. At the provincial level, there are also 
constraints. The main targets for help are the irrigation and power departments (IPDs). These 
are responsible for the program at this level. The IPDs need help similar to that provided to 
AEDB,  albeit  more  focused  on  project  preparation  and  implementation,  private  sector 
participation modalities, evaluation systems, monitoring, and reporting. Financial management, 
fiduciary oversight, and safeguards compliance will be key support areas. These institutions 
also  need  management  support.  They  will  provide  oversight  to  the  project  implementing 
agencies.  They  will  need  coaching  and  assistance  with  policy  reformulation  and  strategic 
planning. Financial accountability will be another major concern. Improvements in accounting 
and auditing while incorporating adequate financial management standards will be necessary to 
ensure fiduciary oversight of disbursed funds. The implementing agencies need and will receive 
training on project preparation (backed by the due diligence teams), project management, 
procurement,  disbursement,  operation  and  maintenance,  financial  management,  and 
compliance with ADB policies and procedures. None of the agencies have been exposed to 
ADB policies in the past. The capacity development component will work on these but also on 
more routine tasks such as evaluation systems, monitoring, and reporting. This is essential. As 
the federal and provincial governments make the warranties and representations to ADB, they 
need information about what happens on the ground. ADB teams need the same information for 
the purposes of reporting to the Management and the Board. Through institutional development, 
implementing agencies will be transformed into commercially oriented entities with functioning 
boards of directors and appointed Chief Executive Officers, supported by operating teams, 
finance, and administration.  
 
3.  Private Sector Participation 
 
35.  The Government wishes to involve the private sector in RE development. In 2002, it set 
out the Policy for Power Generation Projects, which provided a clear set of incentives, along 
with a regulatory regime, to attract private capital. No new independent power producers have 
yet  become  operational,  although  several  are  under  negotiation.  The  provincial  power 
generation policies being prepared by the governments of NWFP and Punjab, based on the 
Policy for Power Generation Projects, will allow wholly owned private sector and public-private 
partnerships as modalities for project development. Within ADB, the public and the private 
sector departments will share information and collaborate on specific transactions, as needed. 
  
4.  Linkage with Global Environment Initiatives 
 
36.  RE  development  will  have  a  positive  impact  on  the  local  and  global  environment. 
Besides reducing atmospheric pollution directly harmful to humans and ecosystems caused by 
the combustion of fossil fuel for power generation, the program will also reduce greenhouse gas 
emissions  and  help  mitigate  climate  change.  Therefore,  RE  development  in  Pakistan  is 
inherently linked with global environment initiatives, such as the Kyoto Protocol, which the 
Government ratified in 2005. Subprojects of the investment program may qualify for the Clean 
Development Mechanism (CDM) as specified in the Protocol. Some of the subprojects, in 
particular wind and solar options, may also qualify for assistance from the GEF. The CDM and 
GEF are expected to enhance the commercial viability of subprojects under the investment 
program. They will also promote private sector participation in RE development. With successful 
private  participation  in  RE  development,  Pakistan  could  demonstrate  such  best  practice 
examples in RE development as models for other DMCs. The application of the CDM and 
support  from  GEF  to  the  investment  program  will  be  examined  during  its  subsequent 
processing. Such support could enhance the financial viability of subprojects and sustainability 
of public-private partnerships. Details are in Supplementary Appendix G.

2.  Technical and Geographical Coverage

plants. Other provinces and geographical areas will require and request finance later. Pakistan

viable for decentralized supplies to remote villages where no other supply option exists and 
where capacities are limited to basic electrification. This resource can also be enhanced through 
innovative pricing and financing for grid-connected households.

F.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
1.  Executing and Implementing Agencies 
 
44.  AEDB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  at  the  federal  level,  while  participating 
provincial governments, acting through respective departments, will be the EAs at their level. 
Provincial agencies dealing with RE will serve as implementing agencies (IAs). The subprojects 
under  the  first  PFR  will  cover  two  provinces,  NWFP  and  Punjab.  Accordingly,  those 
governments’ IPDs will be the EAs at the provincial level. The IAs will be SHYDO in the case of 
NWFP and, until such time that the proposed autonomous corporate body (Punjab Power 
Development Company Limited) is established and fully functioning, Punjab IPD will fulfill that 
role in Punjab. The subproject implementation structure is given in Appendix 7.  
 
45.  SHYDO has established one project management unit (PMU), which is at its main office 
in Peshawar. The PMU will cover three main functions: (i) construction of the three hydropower 
plants; (ii) undertaking feasibility studies, due diligence work, and capacity development; and (iii) 
construction of a new office base. The PMU director and field-level project managers have 
already been appointed. They will report all subproject-related matters to the Director, Planning 
and Facilitation of SHYDO, who is ex-officio the overall coordinator for the NWFP loan.

Company Limited, has been prepared. The provincial government has endorsed the plan and it

IV.  INVESTMENT PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Financial Management 
 
57.  Financial management assessments of each IA were undertaken to assess its ability to 
undertake and fulfill ADB’s fiduciary requirements for the project components. The work was 
based  on  due  diligence  using  financial  management  assessment  questionnaires  and  field 
interviews.  The  financial  management  base  for  the  IAs  was  found  to  be  acceptable 
(Supplementary Appendix I). Any potential fiduciary risks will be minimized through adopting an

18   
accounting and financial management manual13 for Pakistan developed in collaboration with 
ADB. The monitoring and results systems will further strengthen this aspect. Financial analysis 
results are provided in Appendix 9 and details are in Supplementary Appendix J. 
 
B.  Financial Sustainability  
 
58.  Pro forma financial statements were prepared for each IA. SHYDO will be financially and 
operationally independent from NWFP’s provincial government and Punjab Power Development 
Company Limited will be incorporated and operate independently from the Punjab provincial 
government.  ADB  will  monitor  and  ensure  that  this is  the  case  (Appendix  10).  Pro  forma 
financial statements were prepared for the agencies. These include balance sheet entries, profit 
and loss accounts, cash flow statements and operating and financial ratios (all prepared in 
nominal terms). Two IAs are expected to be financially sound from FY2009 onwards. More 
details are available in Supplementary Appendix K. This financial approach and set of controls 
will be adopted also in the cases of new agencies established in the other provinces for the 
purposes of the program. Central and West Asia Department is recruiting financial modeling and 
accounting experts to assist not only with project processing but also with project financial 
monitoring  and  controls.  These  experts  will  be  part  of  the  review  missions  fielded  by  the 
department. The Resident Mission will also play a key role in the supervision process.  
 
59.  A financial evaluation was completed for Part A of the project loan using constant 2006 
prices. The project cost estimates and financial projections were converted into real terms by 
adjusting for the projected effects of foreign and domestic inflation and currency fluctuations. 
Incremental costs and benefits were derived by evaluating the financial position of the IAs under 
a  with-  and  without-project  scenario.  The  average  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR), 
computed on an after-tax basis, is 8.8% for three NWFP projects and 8.1% for five Punjab 
projects. This compares favorably with the average weighted average cost of capital, also 
computed on an after-tax basis of 4.4%. The projects are considered both financially viable and 
sustainable. Cost recovery is expected to be sound. Sensitivity analyses indicate that the FIRR 
for each subproject under the first tranche or first loan is robust and can withstand both tighter 
price variables and higher investment and operating cost scenarios.  
   
C.  Economic Analysis 
 
60.  Economic analysis was undertaken for the first eight subprojects to be financed under 
the first loan. Economic internal rates of return (EIRR) were calculated by comparing with- and 
without-project scenarios for each subproject. Economic benefits accrue to consumers and the 
economy. Incremental consumption occurs due to the extended availability of lower-cost and 
cleaner grid-sourced electricity. This was valued using consumers’ willingness to pay for this 
incremental consumption. Non incremental consumption occurs as consumers replace other 
forms of energy with electricity from the project (the resource cost saving). This was valued on 
the  basis  of  the  estimated  long-run  marginal  cost  (LRMC)  of  electrical  energy  delivery  to 
consumers (Appendix 11).  
 
61.  Estimates indicate that the three proposed hydropower plants in NWFP have EIRRs 
ranging from 15.0% to 21.7%, and that the five proposed hydropower plants in Punjab have 
EIRRs ranging from 17.2% to 20.7%. These EIRRs indicate that the plants are economically

F.  Poverty Assessment 
 
69.  Local  distribution  companies  will  be  encouraged  to  undertake  village  electrification 
programs in some of the proposed project areas, reaching remote and marginalized villages. 
The investment program will provide power to the grid to supply demand. This will benefit 
affected communities. In fact, the greatest part of the newly generated hydropower is expected 
to be delivered to the 11-kilovolt (kV) lines network, while solar and wind are likely to be 
community-based projects and therefore directly used at source. Greater access to reliable 
electricity will contribute to poverty reduction. In fact, reliable electricity supply is a key to 
support  community  services  such  as  education,  healthcare,  and  water  supply.  Access  to 
electricity will improve living conditions in rural areas. Jobs will also be created, and, with this 
greater income, opportunities. The program is also sound on gender grounds. A summary of 
poverty reduction and social strategy is in Supplementary Appendix R.

70.  Businesses, as well as farmers, are also expected to see productivity increases because 
of the program. Moreover, once households and business have electricity, demand for electric 
installations  and  appliances  will  increase.  This  will  create  additional  job  opportunities  and 
trades. In addition, electricity supply improves the quality of life, especially for women, who are 
traditionally responsible for activities inside the house, as well as for fuel collection. Finally, the 
program will bring direct benefits to local communities through upgrading local roads required 
for use during project construction.  
 
G.  Benefits and Beneficiaries under the MFF 
 
71.  The  program  is  designed  to  benefit  all  grid-connected  consumers  of  electricity  by 
expanding electric power supplies, enabling the Government to meet its objective of universal 
electrification under the so-called the “Prime Minister’s Rural Electrification Program.” Electricity 
from small to medium-sized hydropower plants under the investment program will go directly to 
the local grids (at 11 kV or 132 kV), contributing to this key policy objective and helping to fulfill 
provincial  demand  for  greater  energy  resources.  The  overall  objective  of  expanding  clean 
energy generation will contribute to local, regional, and global environmental initiatives. Local air 
quality,  and  particularly  indoor  air  quality,  will  improve  by  the  substitution  of  electricity  for 
biomass  (animal  dung  and  wood)  and  kerosene.  By  expanding  generation  capacity,  the 
Program is expected to result in more reliable power to consumers (particularly benefiting 
commercial, residential, and agriculture customers in the region) and it will result in direct 
positive economic and social benefits. Poor and vulnerable consumers (including hospitals, 
schools, and other social utilities) that are often hardest hit by inadequate power supply, load 
shedding,  and  poor  power  quality,  will  benefit  directly  from  the  investment  program.  The 
Program is expected to create new full-time employment opportunities. For civil works, the 
contractors expect to hire about 100 skilled and 500 unskilled workers for a period of 10 years.  
 
H.  Potential Risks 
 
72.  There are four key broad risk areas for the investment program and they are (i) policy 
framework, (ii) capacity at the agency level (iii) adherence to ADB policies and procedures, and 
(iv)  others.  The  first,  namely  the  policy  framework  is  in  place,  but  some  elements  at  the 
provincial level need to be improved. The risk is mitigated through work at the federal level and 
AEDB (supported by ADB and other donors) and the follow-up to be given by the Ministry of 
Water and Power. The policy framework includes a new tariff regime. This is crucial to ensure 
the financial viability of the program. The connection to the grid is not an issue since most 
operations are meant to be or are expected to be outside of it. But a tariff premium is required to 
back up some of the investments. The regulator has endorsed a tariff regime and, given its 
independence, this is unlikely to be revoked. Equally important is the endorsement of the 
provincial governments. This is in place in some cases, but with some RE resources the work 
has yet to be completed. The policy framework forms part of the warranties and representations 
made by the authorities. ADB has the option to stop financing at any time if this agenda is 
changed or modified in a negative manner. The capacity component provides direct technical 
support in this area. In addition, ADB remains engaged in the sector as a whole through other 
transactions. It will thus have ample entry points for constructive dialogue with federal and 
provincial governments on policy, technical, tariff, governance, and other issues.  
 
73.  The second area covers the capacity at the agency level. Without professional advice 
(national  and  international),  the  agencies  responsible  for  executing  the  program  might  be 
overwhelmed by the tasks at hand and/or make mistakes. Areas at risk include planning, policy 
and project preparation, implementation, new incentives, procedures and systems to invite the

22   
private sector to invest, evaluation, and monitoring. There is also a problem with the quality of 
the reporting systems, methodologies used, and the number and experience of staff. Financial 
management and fiduciary oversight is also a concern. The authorities and ADB propose to deal 
with these risks through the capacity development component. ADB will also make changes by 
diverting additional finance to capacity development, if needed, under subsequent PFRs. 
 
74.  Adherence to ADB operating policies and procedures is the third area. These are part of 
the warranties and representations. Noncompliance with these can halt the program’s financing 
plan and effectively put a stop to new ADB tranches under the facility. The risk is mitigated 
through the capacity component (and action plans thereof), the due diligence plan funded under 
the first few tranches, and ADB program supervision missions. The final or other risks include (i) 
availability and timing of the provision of counterpart funds and inadequate or slow actions on 
consulting services and procurement contracts. The risk of availability of counterpart funds is in 
part mitigated by the program fitting closely with the provincial government’s budget cycle.  The 
risk of funding availability (as opposed to its timing) is more difficult to deal with. ADB will 
monitor the budget process and invite submissions to the higher authorities by the relevant 
officials to ensure that the investment program does not falter on this account. With regard to 
consulting and procurement, ADB will provide support for advance actions and will assist in this 
area by engaging experts on the subject matter.

individual loan and project agreements, as applicable for each project under the MFF, subject to

76.  Counterpart Funding. The Government will ensure, and cause each EA to ensure, the

subprojects. For this purpose, the Government will cause the provinces to ensure that (i) the 
annual development program incorporates revised estimates of the funding requirements for the 
related subprojects under the Facility, and (ii) the funds are released to the assigned accounts.  
 
77.  Land Availability and Resettlement. The provinces will cause each IA to, subject to 
compliance with the relevant provision of the resettlement framework/RPs and EAF/EMP and in 
accordance with all applicable laws and regulations of Pakistan/respective province, acquire or 
make available the land and rights to land free from any encumbrances, and clear utilities, trees, 
and any other obstruction from such land, required for commencement of construction activities 
in accordance with  the schedule agreed under the related civil works contract. 
 
78.  The  provinces  will  cause  respective  IAs,  to  ensure  that  all  land  and  rights-of-way 
required by the subprojects will be made available in a timely manner and that the provisions of

as amended from time to time, and the entitlement benefits as listed in the Government’s 
applicable  laws,  and  ADB’s  Policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995),  and  the  agreed 
resettlement framework. 
 
79.  Environment.  The  Government  and  the  provinces  will  ensure  that  environmental 
assessments of the subprojects are conducted according to ADB’s Environment Policy (2002),

23
the Government’s environmental laws, and the EAF. The Government and the provinces will 
also ensure that (i) the future subprojects will not be located within national parks and wildlife 
sanctuaries, (ii) monuments of cultural or historical importance will be avoided, (iii) an EMP with 
adequate  budget  will  be  developed  for  each subproject, and  (iv)  Environment  Category  A 
subprojects will not be included in the Project.  
 
80.  Social Impacts and Other Issues. In case of any significant or related impacts on tribal

81.  The  provinces  will  ensure  acceptance  of  subprojects  through  effective  community 
participation in selecting and implementing subprojects in accordance with ADB’s safeguard

1.  Pakistan  is  a  water-rich  country.  It  is  endowed  with  about  42,000  Megawatt  (MW) 
hydropower  potential,  most  of  which  is  located  in  North  West  Frontier  Province  (NWFP), 
Northern Areas, Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK), and Punjab. The total installed capacity for 
hydropower stations is about 6,594 MW, of which 3,767 MW is in NWFP, 1,698 MW in Punjab, 
1,036 MW in AJK, and 93 MW in the Northern areas.  
 
2.  The Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) reports some wind data but their quality 
and reliability need to be improved in order to judge the financial and economic viability of the 
proposed investments accurately. It has been argued that the wind speeds are far higher than 
the data imply. Recently, two additional wind stations (50m high) have been built in the Pasni 
area of Balochistan province as part of a project funded by the Global Environment Facility 
(GEF). The measurements from these stations indicate a long-term annual mean wind speed of 
5.5 meters per second (m/s). Existing data indicate good wind conditions in a wind corridor 
extending  from  Gharo  to  Keti-Bandar,  south-east  of  Karachi  in  southern  Sindh.  Wind 
measurements have been undertaken by PMD during 2002-2005 and may have been verified 
by potential private investors who installed their own masts. An average mean wind speed of 7 
m/s or better has been identified at 50 m height. Under such conditions, economically viable 
wind farms can be established provided policy and tariff conditions are adequate.   
 
3.  While some solar data are available from meteorological departments, it is not known 
whether there has been a review of the equipment, accuracy of data, or standards adopted. 
Nevertheless, data for a number of stations have been compiled and they are available in 
international data banks. Taking that data into consideration, sun radiation and daily sunshine 
hours are described as being good to excellent in Balochistan and in some areas of Sindh 
provinces.  Photovoltaic  (PV)  power  is  currently  solely  used  for  single  house  supply  and 
decentralized village supply schemes. About 40 villages were supplied with centralized systems 
some years ago, but most of these are now out of order because of the poor equipment supply, 
and  thus  villagers  are  dissatisfied  with  them.  There  have  also  been  operational  and 
management problems. Recently, the Alternative Energy Development Board (AEDB) supplied 
another 100 households with solar home systems (SHS), for lighting purposes. The barrier to 
this business is the high capital cost of PV systems in the 4.7–7.0 $/per kilowatt range (without 
storage facility). The total cost of PV systems is still currently higher than that of other RE 
systems. However, operational costs are low by comparison, and the operating lifetime is 
considerably higher than most other RE systems (30 years, with a warranty time of 15–25 
years). However, this is only true for the PV modules. In off-grid systems either stand-by 
generators  as  diesel  or  storage  facilities  as  batteries  are  required.  Both  options  increase 
operation and/or capital costs and decrease economic lifetimes. System choice will thus be a 
factor behind the successful development and adoption of this form of RE.  
 
4.  In Pakistan, other than the use of bagasse for self-generation in the sugar industry, and 
some work on better cook stove designs, virtually none of biomass conversion or end use 
technologies has been deployed beyond an experimental stage. Under the RE policy, the 
Government  plans  to  facilitate  the  construction  of  municipal  waste-to-energy  power  plants 
based on landfill methane recovery and/or direct incineration of municipal solid waste, as well as 
methane-based power production from dung-fuelled biodigesters set up by the private sector 
independently or in partnership with the public sector in and around the major towns and cities.  
There is considerable potential for this form of energy.

5.  Risks  for  potential  investors  include  (a)  a  weak  RE-specific  legal  and  regulatory 
framework, especially with regard to the establishment of independent power producers (IPP), 
(b)  the  influence  of  the  Water  and  Power  Development  Authority  (WAPDA)  and  National

agreements (PPA), and (c) an inadequate tariff regime and lack of well designed risk-sharing 
schemes for public and private partnerships. Investment opportunities are also hampered by 
governance constraints and still cumbersome procedures for investor bidding and contract 
awards. 
 
6.  There are major weaknesses at the federal, provincial and project level.  These are 
being dealt with. However, investment programs such as the one targeting RE development 
need targeted and concerted actions if they are to respond to policy, planning, evaluation, 
monitoring,  and  reporting  issues.    Information,  especially  on  best  practice  for  project 
development,  is  scarce  and  capacity  for  project  preparation  (including  due  diligence)  and 
implementation is weak. RE is quite a new concept at both federal and provincial levels. There 
is no clear institutionalized system or practice for the sector, data collection is not extensive, and 
there is limited expertise on economic, technical, financial and safeguards issues. This can 
change quickly but the greatest expertise at the moment lies mostly with traditional energy 
sources. There has been negligible research and development on appropriate technology for 
RE. This is a particular issue for off-grid applications, where site- and region-specific solutions 
are common in other developing countries. Despite being one of the most open economies in 
the  region,  Pakistan  still  faces  lengthy  pre-development  and  negotiation  processes,  which 
impair the supply of equipment and materials.  This affects wind and solar projects in particular, 
for which global supply shortages causes long lead times and price pressures. 
 
7.  A new RE policy framework has been developed for Pakistan. This is supported by 
provincial RE policies based on the renewable energy development road map. The Government 
has  prepared  an  investment  program  for  the  sector.    The  policy  framework  supports  this 
program, which focuses on RE development in the short to medium term (up to 2010). Within 
this period, the Government will finalize a more comprehensive renewable energy policy to 
provide  a  longer-term  development  perspective.  The  Government  has  also  completed 
guidelines for determination of tariff for wind power generation in 2006. ADB has been working 
with the Government on policy issues and on the definition of the proposed investment program.     
 
8.  The Government is aware of the need for private sector participation to deliver volume, 
efficiency and financing. To meet an additional power generation requirement of 143,310 MW 
during 2005–2030, a Medium Term Development Framework 2005–2030 (MTDF) has been 
developed.  The MTDF calls for investment in all sources of energy equivalent to $150 billion 
($6 billion a year), of which about $2 billion a year will come from the public sector. The 
remaining $4 billion will be funded by external sources, including the private sector and banks.  
The private sector will be allowed to operate with a range of project modalities, including build-
operate-transfer (BOT) and private–public partnerships (PPP). Multilateral banks such as ADB 
and the World Bank are also potential financiers. In 2002, the Government set out its Policy for 
Power  Generation  Projects  (PPGP),  providing  a  set  of  incentives,  along  with  a  regulatory 
regime, to attract the private sector. Provincial power generation policies are in the first stage of 
implementation in NWFP and Punjab. These are based on the PPGP and will open the way for 
private sector investment.

exploration and production of oil, gas, and coal resources, as well as the share of alternative 
energy; (ii) through an institutionalized strategy, to optimize utilization of indigenous resources 
to reduce dependence on imported fuel; (iii) to create an environment conducive to private 
sector investment; and (iv) to develop the energy plan from a regional perspective.  
 
3.  Strategy. The strategic vision for development of the energy sector calls for (i) supply to 
be based on an optimal energy mix; (ii) maximum utilization of indigenous resources; (iii)

4.  Road Map for Power Sector Development. The MTDF is based on a road map for the 
power sector that was developed through diagnostic work over several years. This identified 
obstacles to growth and came up with investment and non investment ideas for the medium to 
long term. The investments include private and public sector transactions. To support both, the 
map  also  highlighted  the  need  to  accompany  investments  with  reforms  and  capacity 
development. This is the essence of an investment program for the period of 2005–2015.  
Currently, over 65% of Pakistan’s electricity comes from thermal sources, a little less than 30% 
from hydro, and 1% from other sources. Even with all this imported energy, Pakistan faces a 
20% power shortage. Only 55% of the population has access to electricity from the national grid. 
The remaining 45% uses kerosene, fuel wood, and other forms of biofuels for lighting, cooking, 
and heating. Increase in generation capacity is closely linked to poverty reduction.   
 
5.  Road Map for RE Development. RE development meets the following objectives:  
(i)  Energy  security.  Greater  use  of  indigenous  renewable  resources  can  help 
diversify Pakistan’s energy mix and reduce the country’s dependence on imported fossil 
fuels, thereby helping to mitigate against supply disruptions and price fluctuation risks. 
 
(ii)  Economic benefits to rural communities. When properly assessed for their 
externalities,  RE  options  can  become  as  economically  competitive  as  conventional 
supplies on a least-cost basis. 
 
(iii)  Social equity. Pakistan’s presently low per capita energy consumption can be 
elevated through greater RE use. Issues relating to social equity—such as equal rights 
and access for all citizens to modern energy supplies, and reducing poverty in deprived 
sections of society—can also be addressed through widespread RE deployment. 
 
(iv)  Environmental protection.  Local environmental and health impacts of fossil 
fuel-powered electricity generation can be largely avoided through clean, RE alternatives. 
Similarly,  displacing  greenhouse  gas  emissions  can  yield  significant  global  climate 
change benefits, towards which Pakistan has pledged action under the Kyoto Protocol.

for its approval. The Government has delegated authority to the provinces to develop their own 
generating capacities of up to 50 MW and to place greater emphasis on RE. RE development is 
fully compatible with the Government’s twin goals of energy security1 and promoting indigenous 
resource utilization. RE development is also one of the key features of the Government’s 
poverty reduction agenda. The renewable energy development road map presents a clear and 
comprehensive package of investments and changes in several areas, including regulatory, 
legislative, and financial. It also makes provisions for investment incentives, private sector 
participation, better and more transparent procedures for bids and contract awards, governance, 
and fiduciary oversight. The RE development road map, which is presented below, calls for (i)
