ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF EIGHT SUBPROJECTS 
 
A.  Assumptions 
 
1.  All costs and benefits have been expressed at constant June 2006 price levels. The 
domestic price numeraire was used; tradable inputs were valued at their border price equivalent 
values and were converted to domestic equivalents using an estimated standard exchange rate 
factor  of  1.11.  Capital  costs  included  physical  contingencies  but  excluded  taxes,  price 
contingencies, and financial charges during construction. The official exchange rate as of June 
2006 has been taken as PRs60 = $1. A variable cost (excluding staff costs) of PRs0.0001/kWh 
and a fixed cost of 3% of capital cost were assumed. A plant overhaul costing 20% of capital 
cost after 10 years was also assumed. Station use of 0.5% of gross generation, and peak and 
off-peak transmission losses of 2% and 1% of gross generation respectively, were assumed, as 
were peak and off-peak technical distribution losses of 15% and 8%, respectively. An oil price of 
$40 per barrel (bbl) has been used as a base case for economic internal rate of return (EIRR) 
calculations, and sensitivities tested higher bound oil prices of $35/bbl and $50/bbl.  
 
B.  Least-Cost analysis 
 
2.  For the purposes of establishing that the subprojects were least cost, the National 
Transmission and Dispatch Company (NTDC) was requested to undertake the specific Wien 
Automatic System Planning (WASP) runs. The WASP IV program is the primary means by 
which  NTDC  undertakes  least-cost  planning  for  electricity  generation.  NTDC’s  energy  and 
demand forecast for supply from the national grid for 2010, 2015, and 2020 are 17.4, 26.8, and 
38.0  thousand  MW,  respectively.  Demand-supply  analysis  based  upon  the  medium-term 
forecast shows that the NTDC system will have capacity shortfalls in 2006, 2008, and 2010 of 
400, 1,200 and 5,138 MW, respectively. Capacity includes all ongoing and committed projects. 
The least-cost expansion plan included all types of candidate plants, covering (i) hydroelectric 
plants for which feasibility studies are underway or are planned, (ii) coal-fired plants using local 
coal, (iii) base load combined cycle plants fired by imported and domestic gas, (iv) open cycle 
gas  turbines  fired  by  local  and  imported  gas,  and  (v)  other  plants.  More  details  are  in 
Supplementary Appendix L.  
 
C.  Calculation of Willingness to Pay (WTP) 
 
3.  The  subprojects  produce  both  incremental  and  nonincremental  outputs.  Incremental 
output was valued using consumers’ willingness to pay (WTP). Nonincremental output was 
valued using the estimated long-run marginal costs (LRMCs) of peak and off-peak energy. The 
status of the high-head subprojects as peaking stations means that nearly 100% of output 
during the four-hour peak period can be deemed incremental. For low-head subprojects, the 
split between incremental and non incremental output was estimated using a with- and without- 
subprojects analysis in WASP IV, resulting in approximately 50% of output during the four-hour 
peak period being deemed incremental. LRMC derived on the basis of thermal equivalent 
provides a static simplification of the dynamic nature of the power system, as it assumes that 
the marginal plant is constant and that the plant factor of the proposed project is constant. To 
avoid this simplification, peak energy and off-peak energy LRMCs for the without-subprojects 
case were determined at the grid level using WASP IV and were adjusted as appropriate to 
reflect the voltage level at which benefits would be delivered. The economic benefits of the 
subprojects have thus been estimated as (i) incremental output valued at consumers’ estimated 
WTP, (ii) nonincremental peak-period output (assumed to be 4 hours/day) valued at the LRMC 
of peak energy at the appropriate or applicable voltage level, and (iii) nonincremental off-peak-

61   
period output (assumed to be 20 hours/day) valued at the LRMC of off-peak energy at the 
appropriate voltage level.  
 
4.  WTP was estimated by comparing current electricity prices against the price of the 
alternative  source  of  energy  for  each  of  four  consumer  classes  (residential,  agricultural, 
commercial, and industrial), and by assuming that consumers will be willing to pay a proportion 
of the difference between what they would be required to pay for an alternative energy source 
and what they would actually pay for the additional units of energy delivered by the subprojects. 
Residential consumers typically use kerosene lamps for reserve lighting when grid-supplied 
electricity is unavailable (constrained off), as they represent the next best viable alternative from 
an economic perspective. The economic lifecycle cost of kerosene lamps is approximately 
PRs28/kWh. 
 
5.  In the commercial, industrial, and agricultural sectors, diesel generators are typically 
employed to provide backup electricity when grid-supplied electricity is unavailable or when the 
voltage is too low for proper operation of electrical equipment. Thus, diesel generators were 
used as the next best alternative at an estimated lifecycle cost of PRs14/kWh. Incremental 
consumption is expected to accrue partially as a consequence of improved availability releasing 
suppressed  demand  and  partially  as  a  consequence  of  improved  supply  quality.  This 
complicates estimation of WTP for incremental consumption of residential consumers. In lieu of 
detailed household energy use data, and particularly in relation to the impact of supply quality 
on demand, it has been conservatively assumed that, for residential consumers, 33% of the 
difference between tariff and alternative energy sources represents consumer surplus. For other 
consumer classes, a linear demand function has been assumed, with 50% of the difference 
between the marginal tariff and alternative energy cost representing consumer surplus. 
 
D.  Estimation of Costs and Benefit 
 
6.  Economic  costs  exclude  taxes,  price  contingencies,  and  financial  charges  during 
construction. The main benefit of the subprojects is electricity generation to meet electricity 
demand (incremental output) and to displace more expensive thermal plant (non incremental 
output). Incremental output was valued using consumers’ estimated willingness to pay (WTP). 
Non incremental output was valued using the estimated long-run marginal costs (LRMCs) of 
peak and off-peak energy. The split between incremental and nonincremental output for low-
head schemes was estimated using a with- and without- subprojects analysis in WASP IV, 
resulting  in  approximately  50%  of  output  during  the  four-hour  peak  period  being  deemed 
incremental. For high-head schemes, their status as peaking plants means that 100% of output 
during the four-hour peak period being can be deemed incremental. On the basis of estimated 
costs of alternative energy sources and average marginal tariffs for each consumer sector, the 
WTPs  for  incremental  consumption  were  estimated  as  (i)  residential:  PRs13.65/kWh,  (ii) 
agricultural: PRs8.2/kWh (NWFP) and PRs8.4/kWh (Punjab), (iii) commercial: PRs10.5/kWh, 
and (iv) industrial: PRs9.0/kWh. Weighted WTPs of PRs12.17/kWh (NWFP) and PRs12.19/kWh 
(Punjab) were thus used as the unit value for incremental output.

A.  Introduction and Description of the Investment Program 
 
1.  The proposed Renewable Energy (RE) Development Sector Investment Program will 
develop eight subprojects that were evaluated under a technical assistance1. The Implementing 
Agency (IA) for five of the subprojects located in Punjab is the Irrigation and Power Department 
(IPD), whereas the Sarhad Hydel Development Organization (SHYDO) is the IA for the three

of the Government are identical to those of ADB for hydropower projects of less than 50 MW. 
An  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  is  required  to  be  submitted  to  the  relevant 
environmental protection authority, the Punjab Environmental Protection Department in Punjab 
or the North-West Frontier Province (NWFP) Environmental Protection Agency in NWFP. The

environmental  policy  and  guidelines 2  and  the  Government’s  environmental  assessment

B.  Description of the Environment 
 
2.  Punjab Province: Punjab forms part of Indus Basin Watershed System. The landscape 
of the whole province has been changed completely by development in the last 100 years of the 
largest canal system in the world. The subprojects are located in plain areas with elevation in 
the range of 50–150 m above mean sea level. The subproject areas fall in a moist temperate 
zone that receives rains in the summer monsoon. Some residual precipitation is also received in 
the winter months due to western Mediterranean winds. The lowest and highest values of mean 
monthly maximum temperature are about 5° C and 42° C during the months of January and 
June, respectively. The soils of the subproject areas are characterized as alluvium deposits of 
sandy loam and sandy silt. According to the Seismo-Tectonic Map of Pakistan, the subproject 
area belongs to one of the least active earthquake zones in the country, rated Zone 0. The 
canals deliver an almost uniform irrigation water flow for 11 months of the year. The people of 
the subproject areas depend upon the canals to meet their household water needs.  
 
3.  Because of extensive cultivation, high population, and human activities, there is little 
wildlife in the subproject areas. There are no protected areas close to any of the subproject 
areas. There are no natural forests in the vicinity of the subproject areas. However, the trees 
along canals planted by irrigation and power departments and forestry departments fall in the 
category of reserved forests. Local farmers are practicing a small degree of farm-forestry to 
meet their fuel wood and other day-to-day needs. Ever since the irrigation canal system was 
developed,  cotton,  rice,  sugarcane  and  wheat  have  been  the  main  crops.  More  recently, 
however, cotton and sugar cane cultivation has been replaced by maize and potatoes in many 
areas. The fisheries department reports that the main fish species found in the canal system are 
Gulfam,  Rahoo,  and  Mohri.  Because  of  the  construction  of  several  barrages  on  the  river 
network, migratory species have almost become extinct in Punjab waters.  
 
4.  The subproject areas have a reasonably well-developed communication infrastructure 
linked to the irrigation and farming network. At the highest level are the National Highway N-5 
and other highways such as Gujranwala-Sialkot road. Other cities and towns are connected to

Geology and Tectonics map, the main earthquake centers fall within a circle of 50 km radius 
around Madyan. The Daral Khawar and Ranolia area is in a relatively calm zone.  
 
7.  The common mammals reported from the Daral Khawar and Ranolia areas and their 
adjoining valleys are monkeys, markhor, musk deer, black bear, brown bear, wolf, leopard cat, 
and panther. Besides common birds, some significant species of the project area are Himalayan 
chakor,  snow  cock,  koklas  pheasant,  and  snow  partridge.  There  are  a  variety  of  highly 
endangered and rare pheasants in the Kohistan area, including monal, white crested Khalij, 
snow cock, Koklas, snow partridge, and the most endangered western tragopan. Snow leopard, 
brown bear, musk deer and snow partridge have declining population and are classified as 
endangered species. In the immediate Ranolia site area there is degraded habitat and no threat 
exists to any rare or endangered species. Forests in the entire Swat and Kohistan area fall into 
the  protected  category.  The  subproject  areas  have  high  hill  coniferous  forests,  which  are 
associated with the dry-temperate climate zone. Very limited data is available for fish species in 
the Swat River system, and almost none for Daral Khwar, which is a tributary of the same. The 
fish species known as Swati (Schizothorax plagiostomas) is found in most rivers of NWFP. 
Brown trout have been introduced to Swat River, where, in certain streams they have done well. 
The socioeconomic status of the project area has been described in detail in the IEE.  
 
C.  Environmental Impacts and Mitigation 
 
8.  The subprojects will provide electric power to the wider population. The subprojects will 
provide  unskilled  jobs  during  the  construction  phase  and  a  limited  number  of  jobs  during 
operations. Hydropower is a clean and renewable source of energy and avoids contributing to 
the pollution loads that would result from the alternative use of thermal electricity generation. 
The subprojects will result in reduced greenhouse gas emissions, with potential for carbon credit 
transactions. In addition to the trees on private land that will be affected by the subprojects, 
trees in the rights-of-way of the canals and on government land would be lost due to clearing of 
land required for the construction work. To compensate for this, tree planting will be undertaken

Appendix 13  65 
in all eight subprojects. Provisions have been made to plant more than 200,000 trees over 19 ha 
in  the  subprojects.  Construction  activities  on  the  subprojects  are  likely  to  have  short-term 
adverse impacts. To mitigate the impacts, environmental controls have been proposed in the 
environmental management plans (EMPs) included in the IEEs.  
 
9.  In the absence of specific Pakistan guidelines for the amount of water (residual water) to 
be retained in a watercourse when water is extracted for hydropower purposes, the standards 
used in Western Europe (e.g., Switzerland) were used. The minimum residual water flow to be 
left in Daral Khwar and Ranolia Rivers as determined by this standard (and rounded up to 
nearest  multiple  of  100)  is  700  liters/second  and  500  liters/second,  respectively.  Water 
monitoring quality programs are proposed to assess impacts of reduced water flows in the two 
rivers and impacts upon water users. The powerhouses constructed in the low-head subprojects 
will be connected to the national grid by 11-kV transmission lines to the nearest grid station. The 
maximum length of these lines is 20 km. The lines will be installed in the existing rights-of-way 
of the canals, and therefore no land acquisition is envisaged. The Ranolia and Daral Khwar 
powerhouses will be connected to the national grid by 36 km of 33-kV transmission line and 12 
km of 66-kV transmission line, respectively. To the extent possible, the lines will follow the 
existing road and will be constructed within the existing road right-of-way. Where this is not 
possible, land will be acquired for which provisions are available in the budget. The transmission 
lines will not pass through any protected area, or other environmentally sensitive areas. 
 
D  Environmental Management Plan and Institutional Requirements 
 
10.  The IAs will obtain approvals for their IEEs from the respective environmental protection 
agencies. The IAs will also monitor their respective subprojects and forward monitoring reports 
on a regular basis to the provincial environmental protection agencies as per the regulatory 
requirements.  The  IA  will  ensure  that  environmental  conditions  are  included  in  project 
construction contract documents. To handle their general environmental and land compensation 
responsibilities, the IAs will develop the capacity and allocate human resources to implement 
the EMP and Resettlement Plan. Part C of the investment program covers a major capacity 
development effort. The IAs will also appoint an environment and resettlement officer. Terms of 
reference for this position are included in the IEE. 
 
11.  A detailed mitigation plan was prepared as part of the EMP. The mitigation plan contains 
a  comprehensive  listing  of  mitigation  actions,  the  persons  responsible  for  ensuring  full 
implementation of each action, the persons responsible for monitoring the action, and a time 
scale for implementation of the action to ensure that the objectives of mitigation are fully met. 
The mitigation measures will be translated into environmental requirements and specifications 
for detailed design and construction and will be legally binding. Two types of monitoring will be 
conducted: compliance monitoring and impact or effect monitoring. Compliance monitoring will 
be the responsibility of the IA and all other organizations involved in the field activities. The 
effects monitoring will be carried out in line with the requirements in the mitigation plan, focusing 
on fish and water quality impacts. The total cost of the environmental mitigation and monitoring 
measures for the eight subprojects is about PRs62.1 million ($1.03 million). 
 
E.  Conclusions 
 
12.  The  subprojects  will  have  very  little  adverse  environmental  impacts.  The  adverse 
impacts will be adequately mitigated as described in the EMP, which IAs are committed to 
implement.  However,  IAs  will  obtain  maximum  benefits  from  the  capacity  development 
component of the investment program. The IAs will improve their capacities to implement and 
monitor the measures in the EMP. Based on the review conducted to date, ADB environment 
category B is appropriate and a full environmental impact assessment is not necessary.

66  Appendix 14 
SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN OF RANOLIA HYDROPOWER PLANT 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Ranoia Hydropower Plant (Rhydropower plant) subproject is situated on a natural 
mountain stream, known as Ranolia Khwar, which gets its water from perennial springs and 
melting snow. About 6.0 ha of privately owned forest and agricultural land will need to be 
acquired permanently from individual landowners for construction of this power plant. A 33-kV 
transmission line will be constructed along Karakorum Highway to Besham (20 km) within its 
right-of-way, for which no land acquisition will be necessary. An additional 0.15 ha land has to 
be acquired temporarily by the contractor for establishing a construction camp and storage of 
equipment and material. A total of 24 households will be affected, two of which significantly. As 
a result of the consultations, the design of the proposed weir was changed to ensure a minimum 
of 500 litres/second of residual water flow into the Ranolia Khwar even during the winter.  
 
B.  Policy Framework and Entitlements 
 
2.  The  Government  of  Pakistan  and  the  four  provinces,  including  North- 
West Frontier Province, use the Land Acquisition Act of 1894 (LAA), with amendments, as the 
core  legal  document  for  acquiring  private  land  for  public  purposes.  The  process  of  land 
acquisition is initiated by serving a preliminary notice under Section 4 of the Act by the District 
Revenue  Officer  (DRO),  acting  as  the  land  acquisition  collector  (LAC),  expressing  the 
Government’s intention to "enter upon" the identified private lands for surveying and soil-testing 
for a specified public purpose. The next activity is carried out under Section 5, which involves 
marking  and  measuring  the  land  and  assessing  compensation.  The  final  declaration  for 
possession of the selected portions or strips of land is issued under Section 6 of the LAA. 
 
3.  Under the LAA, only persons officially registered as owners with the Land Revenue 
Department  or  who  possess  formal  lease  agreements  are  considered  eligible  for  land 
compensation. As per the provisions of the Act, cash compensation is assessed (Section 5) on 
the basis of average registered land sale transfer rates for the latest 3–5 years and is paid to the 
landowners for their lands being acquired.1 However, there have been instances in the near 
past of taking average rates of the past 1 year, and even taking the current rates. For land 
acquisition for this project, nevertheless, the current open-market rates or replacement value will 
be  applied,  as  per  ADB’s  resettlement  policy,  and  the  process  of  land  acquisition  will  be 
shortened by replacing formal LAA mechanisms with direct negotiations with the landowners 
and their village elders. In the absence of a formal policy, a project-specific set of resettlement 
principles consistent with ADB resettlement policy2 requirements has been adopted for this 
ADB-funded project.

C.  Information Dissemination, Consultation, Disclosure, and Grievance Redress 
 
4.  Subprojects information has been disclosed and disseminated by the Executing Agency 
(EA) through public consultation. A resettlement information leaflet containing information on 
compensation and resettlement options was made available in local languages and distributed 
to affected persons. The project management unit (PMU) through Environmental and Social 
Development Cell (ESDC) and the PMUs has conduct consultations in affected villages to 
explain the resettlement plan in coordination with village and community leaders. Each affected 
person will be provided information regarding specific entitlements. Disputes on entitlements 
can  be  forwarded  to  the  project  implementation  unit  for  appropriate  action.  The  summary 
resettlement plan (RP) will be disclosed on the ADB website, and information dissemination and 
consultation will continue throughout the project implementation period. 
 
5.  A  grievance  redress  committee  (GRC)  will  be  formed  to  ensure  affected  persons’ 
grievances are addressed and appropriated actions are taken to resolve them. The committee 
members of a GRC will include affected person representatives, and especially representatives 
of vulnerable affected persons, local-level IA/PMU staff, local governments, respected citizens 
in diverse professions, non government organizations (NGOs), community-based organizations, 
and local civil and interest groups. The head of a locally elected body will head the GRC. The 
GRC will meet every 2 weeks especially during the land acquisition and resettlement phase. 
After  that,  it  will  meet  as  and  when  grievances  are  referred  to  it  to  redress.  The  main 
responsibilities of the GRC are to (i) help APs’ in resolving issues arising from land and property 
acquisition  processes;  (ii)  record,  categorize,  prioritize,  and  resolve  APs’  grievances;  (iii) 
immediately inform the PMU of serious issues and problems; and (iv) inform affected persons of 
the decisions of the GRC and PMU. Each GRC will review grievances involving all resettlement 
benefits,  compensation,  relocation,  and  other  assistance.  Detailed  investigation  will  be 
undertaken  which  may  involve  field  investigation  with  the  affected  persons  concerned. 
Grievances will be redressed within 2–3 weeks from the dates of lodging the complaints. The 
GRC will continue to function during the life of the project, including the defects liability period.  
 
D.  Compensation and Income Restoration 
 
6.  All affected persons will be provided with compensation and resettlement assistance if 
their  lands  are  permanently  or  temporarily  acquired,  their  income  sources  are  adversely 
affected, their homes are fully or partially affected, and such other properties as commercial or 
agricultural structures, crops, trees, and other facilities or access to properties are damaged or 
reduced due to subprojects. Lack of legal documents of their customary rights of occupancy or 
titles shall not affect their eligibility for compensation. In case of land acquisition where land-for-
land is not a feasible option, the RP stipulates payment of compensation based on assessed 
replacement or market value of land and structures to affected persons. Temporary land losers 
will be in charge of land clearance and will be therefore compensated for the provision of labor 
at the minimum agricultural wage rate for the duration of this activity.  
 
7.  In addition to compensation payments in accordance with the LAA, affected persons will 
receive  additional  assistance  to  match  replacement  costs  (the  difference  between  the 
replacement value and the assessed value) for lost land and structures; transaction costs 
including but not limited to stamps and registration costs for the purchase of replacement land; 
and other forms of resettlement assistance such as transition and shifting allowances, and 
agricultural inputs for re-establishing crops. Losses of profits and income due to property loss or 
loss of access to property, regardless of whether the affected person is titled or non-titled, will 
be compensated. To restore income losses, there will be compensation for lost workdays and/or

Appendix 14    69 
income. Eligible affected persons, both titled and non-titled, will be provided rental income for 
temporary acquisition. Loss of structures shall be compensated according to the provisions 
included  in  the  entitlements  matrix.  Restoration  for  any  disruption  occurred  during  the 
implementation on temporarily acquired land shall be undertaken by the contractor. 
 
E.  Institutional Framework, Resettlement Costs, and Implementation Schedule 
 
8.  A  PMU  will  be  established  in  Sarhad  Hydel  Development  Organization  (SHYDO) 
headquarters in Peshawar. The PMU will be responsible for overall implementation of the 
poject. Each IAs will create its respective administrative unit, the ESDC, consisting of two 
members: an environmental specialist and a resettlement specialist.3 The ESDC will work in 
close cooperation with the respective field-based office on the day-to-day activities of the Short 
Resettlement Plan implementation. At present SHYDO does not fully possess the expertise and 
experience required for implementing the RP and verifying and revising the data on affected 
lands and assets presented herein after the revision and finalization of the project design. The 
PMU  through  ESDC  field  offices,  district  land  acquisition  collector  (LAC/DRO),  and  the 
Resettlement  Specialist  will  monitor  the  progress  of  the  work.  That  specialist  will  ensure 
coordination between the relevant departments, the grievance redress committee and the APs.

F.  Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
9.  Internal monitoring of implementation will be the responsibility of the PMO and engaged 
NGOs.  The  ESDC  internal  monitoring  will  include  (i)  administrative  monitoring  (planning, 
implementation,  feedback  and  troubleshooting,  AP’s  file  maintenance,  and  preparation  of 
progress  reports),  (ii)  socioeconomic  monitoring  (case  studies,  development  of  baseline 
information on APs’ socioeconomic conditions, compensation payment, grievance resolution, 
relocation, payment of other entitlements etc), and (iii) impact evaluation monitoring (calculation 
of compensation payment rates, quality of resettlement sites if any, consultation programs, and 
restoration  and  improvement  of  income  standards  and  livelihoods  against  established 
benchmarks).  Monitoring  and  evaluation  reports  documenting  progress  on  resettlement 
implementation and RP completion reports will be provided by ESDC to ADB for review.  
 
10.  The EA will engage the services of an independent agency not associated with project 
implementation to undertake external monitoring and evaluation of resettlement implementation. 
The external monitoring agency will have experience in resettlement implementation and a 
satisfactory  familiarity  with  lands  laws  and  regulations  and  ADB’s  involuntary  resettlement 
policy. It will be hired in consultation with ADB within 3 months of the loan effectiveness. The 
agency will monitor and verify RP implementation to determine whether resettlement goals have 
been achieved and livelihood and living standards have been restored or improved. It will 
highlight  weaknesses  in  the  implementation  process  with  recommendations  on  how  to 
overcome them. The external monitoring of the project will be done twice a year and impact 
evaluation during the midterm review of resettlement implementation and at the end of the 
subproject. Monitoring will indicate whether affected persons understood their entitlements and 
their views on resettlement site conditions. It will evaluate compensation valuation methods and 
disbursement, grievance redress procedures, and staff competencies. The external monitor will 
also evaluate the performance of the ESDC, PMU, and NGOs. The external agency will report 
its findings simultaneously to the EA and to ADB twice a year. Provisions will be made in each 
RP for engaging an external resettlement implementation monitor.
